name: 1-iodonaphthalene
Reason: Starting with the base structure, naphthalene has a melting point of 80.2 degrees Celsius. The presence of an iodine substituent affects the melting point in several ways. Firstly, the addition of an iodine atom significantly increases the molecular weight, which generally increases the melting point due to stronger London dispersion forces. However, the iodine atom also perturbs the crystalline structure of naphthalene, which can disrupt the close packing of the molecules and potentially lower the melting point. The size of the iodine atom and its ability to serve as a temporary dipole also means that it can increase the strength of intermolecular interactions, potentially raising the melting point. Taking both effects into account, the large size and heavy weight of iodine is expected to have a greater influence in raising the melting point. The effect of an iodine substituent on the melting point can be estimated to increase it by approximately -76.1 Celsius (comparing iodonaphthalene to naphthalene gives a difference of 80.2 - 4.1 = 76.1), as its electron cloud and heavy atomic weight dominate the intermolecular interactions rather than the disruption of crystal packing.

name: 1-iodonaphthalene
Reason: Starting with the base structure naphthalene, which has a melting point of 80.2 degrees Celsius. The introduction of an iodine atom to the naphthalene ring generally increases the molecule's molecular weight which contributes to stronger London dispersion forces, typically leading to an increase in melting point. However, the actual melting point of 1-iodonaphthalene is significantly lower, indicating that the presence of the iodine atom disrupts the molecular packing in the solid phase more than it contributes to intermolecular attraction via increased London forces. The large atomic radius and electron cloud of iodine can impose steric hindrance and affect crystal lattice stability, leading to a decrease in the melting point. Another factor to consider is the polarizability of iodine; while it does contribute to stronger van der Waals interactions, these seem to be insufficient to offset the disruptive effect on the crystal lattice. Thus, the decrease due to the iodine substituent can be quantitatively reasoned to be 80.2 - 4.1 = 76.1 Celsius.
